author: Monty
title: Does what it says on the tin.
review: As people seem to have reviewed this I thought why not add my views. This is a very useful tool for separating bricks that are stuck fast - sometimes having two - one on each part is necessary. It strikes me it would have been very useful to have when I was younger as much of my surviving childhood Lego bears many teeth marks which is how I recall we used to separate bricks in the old days - especially when the tiles did not have a little groove around the bottom – not that this would help you there as it needs studs or holes to lock into. Anyway, it does what is says it does – separates bricks!

author: Imperial13
title: Good. just good, not anything to get excited about.
review:
As the title sais this is nothing to get all happy about (like clearer pictures of Indy Sets). I actually got this in the mindstorms RCX  package, so no tin for me;-( you really need two to experiance the coolness!
                   
                                                                Imperial13   )o(
                                                                                    I I

author: jof
title: not at that price
review:
I have 2 of these from various sets & they are invaluable.

I don't know how long I can keep them in use with 3 small kids to loose them & a lot of 'use this, not your teeth!'

However, to attempt to sell them at £1.99 each is a real rip off (Legoland windsor).

author: Gus_263
title: Decent Brick
review: This set is just a brick, I got this with my first Lego set (4152), a bucket with a lot of different bricks, released in 1995. This brick, of course serves to separate other bricks and plates, and it works very well in some bricks but sometimes it don't separate so easy. Altough this looks like to be unuseful, this brick don't have problems, and sometimes separate hard pieces, it is sometimes neccessary (If you don't want separate hard pieces with your teeth). But, altough it can do somethings more easily, it isn't motive to pay much for it. If you find it with another set, in a bucket with lot of pieces, it will be a good addition. And if you don't find it in any set, pay for it, it can be found in some Legolands, but don't pay more than 2,5 dollars, it is just a brick. Overall, it can separate some hard pieces, and makes it easily, sometimes. So, in comparison with other bricks, it gets a 4,8/5.

author: legoman4694
title: VERY useful
review: i got this in a lego designer set from 2003. it was very use ful. i was tired of having to pull apart bricks (the flat ones) with my finger or attaching them to other bricks. its good if you get it with another set but dont buy it by its self!

author: Obi_Wan9994
title: Fast and Efficent!
review:
I got this in a bin of legos for free, and let me tell you, it's saved me lots of time and effort in taking my Legos apart.

Pros:
Takes apart your Lego bricks, not Technic pieces
Not exacly sure of the price, but I know they're really cheap
Saves Time and effort
It's only one piece, so don't worry about it falling apart

There isn't much to say about this other than that. If you don't have one, I'd highly recommend getting one.

author: jpmanalo
title: Essential!
review:
The Brick Separator is one one of the most useful items a LEGO builder will have in their collection. 
 
Not only will the brick separator separate bricks and tiles, but it'll also save your fingernails! 
 
Philippe E. Hurbain (Better known amongst many AFOLs as "Philo") has a really good description regarding the use of the brick separator on his website:
http://www.philohome.com/remover/remover1.htm 
 
Set 630-1 is identical to this, except the Brick Separator is green.

author: bmwlego
title: Invaluable LEGO Tool!
review:
I got this tool in a Creator Dino set. I love it and when I am MOC'ing I always have it by my side on the table. It is the perfect tool for separating those tough to pull apart plates. You just apply a tiny bit of pressure and the tool separates plates with the greatest of ease. As a kid I would place the LEGO plates in between my teeth and try to separate them! If this was around when I built with LEGO as a kid my childhood LEGO would not have teeth marks on them!
Great solution to a very common problem! Thank you LEGO!

author: Zapp_Brannigan
title: Pretty useful
review: I didn't actually get this on its own, but it came with set 4153. It's nice to have something to pull apart plates, however, sometimes 2 plates that stick together hard can be painstaking to separate, even with this simple machine. The idea is to slowly pry them apart, because when being separated, the bottom plate's studs can drill into the top plate's underside where it clutches. As a result, the dented plate's clutch power can be weakened, and in extreme cases, stress the plate enough so that it cracks. Overall, useful tool, but use carefully to ensure the highest possible warranty of bricks and plates.

author: thenaterater
title: works pretty well
review: this works to separate bricks. it works the very best if you have a brick stuck on to a baseplate, sometimes it will not work if you have two smaller bricks stuck together, but it usually works, and as a kid, it reminded me of a vaccum

author: legoguy_3000_
title: extremly useful
review:
I was going to rate this 3/5 because I didn't know how it worked until my brother showed me how. now i've rated it 5/5. Now I can seperate any basic bricks apart. You put your thumb on the hole near the studs and hold it round the lines at the back. then you put the holes underneath the studs on the brick you want to separate. then push your hand down and the bricks separate.

pros:
very useful for separating basic bricks

cons:
hard to get

5/5

author: MetroiD
title: This chunk of classic grey used to be vital - until the emergence of neon orange
review:
When I first saw this tool, its functionality was completely lost on me and I ended up using it as a chunky, oversized antenna - imagine the size of TV set I had come up with. I took me some time to grasp how the Separator separates, but once I realized just how great it can be with plates, it was always by my side: remember, the clutch power of last-century LEGO could at times transcend the laws of physics... In terms of ergonomics, the "classic" separator has a very nice, chunky feel to it and my thumb always enjoyed having that rounded indent as its designated spot.

However, the Separator was not particularly useful when dealing with tiles - yes, it did have a slight edge at the front which was supposed to help with those but working with that was a hit or a miss kind of experience. Furthermore, its scope of operation was always limited to just "System" - i.e. forget about Technic. Which is why, especially in light of the emergence of "modern" orange / green separators, this one realistically needs to be docked one point.

Having noted the above though, while underlining that the current orange separator is more functional and has a wider range of applications, I must still note that this big ol' chunk of grey feels decidedly more comfortable in my hand. It might just be the nostalgia, but it's well and truly a symbol of "Classic System" - and you can't beat that.

author: pillowranch
title: Lego Separator
review:
If you are a pro Lego builder or just a guy that likes to mess around, this is the water and bread of Lego building.
I highly recommend this to anyone.
Very easy to use and very durable and quite cheap!

author: Alemas
title: I've got TWO of these!
review:
I've got one from LEGOLAND, and another inside Wild Collection(strange)! These are ESSENTIAL if you don't want to use your teeth! It's a must-have!

Pros:

Can remove bricks
Nice-looking

Cons:

None!

Overall, an essential tool!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: A Must Have Tool!
review:
Tired of breaking your nails (and your teeth) trying to separate two bricks? Look no further, the brick separator is for you!


Building Experience: One piece, no building experience.

Parts: I'll take this time to explain how useful the tool is. The over sized stud holes on the bottom grip the brick and easily pull it off. The same works for the top studs. This is one of the most helpful pieces in my collection.


Playability: It's a tool, not a toy


Value for Money: Great value (I got it free with a LEGO mosaic). $2 is a great deal for a tool like this.


Final Words: This is a must have tool for any LEGO Builder. Not only does it save you from painful finger bruises, it also removes bricks with ease.

author: Pepper
title: pretty useful
review:
This set is useful for separating pretty much any Lego (not technic) pieces that are stuck together. I am glad that I got it for free from a friend in a tub of Legos.

pros:
-easy to use
-works well

cons.
-none

Overall, this set is pretty nice. It also looks better than the green one.

author: Cole_
title: Must have!
review:
This is a great set, and a must have for LEGO collectors. Here are the Pros and Cons:

  • Pros:
  • Easy to build(only one piece).
  • Easy to use, just click and pull.

  • Cons: 
  • Nothing!

author: Carnigee77
title: Good for the model builder.
review: This set (just one piece) is really handy! Although it may be a little bit overpriced, it has helped me out of a jam many times. You also need 2 to get some pieces apart. They come in different colors, but the grey looks the most natural sitting a place ready to be used.

author: wander099
title: A Life-Saver!
review:
My parents bought me this tool when I got my first lego sets and I'm really glad that they did, it has proved a very useful tool over the years.

While larger blocks are relatively easy to pull apart, sometimes the smaller blocks are harder to get a grip on, especially if they are flat pieces that are in the middle of a larger brick.  Also, I'm sure we've all had those situations where two bricks of the same size have become seemingly fused together and we just can't pull them apart.  I've found this tool invaluable in helping me with such situations.

Overall, I think this is a must have for lego collectors young and old.  It reduces the time required to disassemble sets or correct mistakes during construction.  Additionally, it can pull apart those pieces that seem impossible to separate.  Obviously, as it is a tool, it has no building value, playability value, or pieces in itself, but as a tool it is well worth the price.

author: TooMuchLEGO
title: Most useful tool LEGO has ever made.
review: This tool is very, VERY useful. If you are like me and you have to constantly use your fingernails to rip off tiny LEGO pieces, then this will be your best friend. As you may know, some pieces are so stuck together you may think they will never separate. But the Brick separator will yank them apart. The only thing it can't really do is take apart minifigures, but since they usually aren't a problem, it's really quite OK. My last word? Get the brick separator!

author: Cult_Of_Skaro
title: Click! Tada!
review: You have a model. You want to make a new one. The only problem is that there's these two darn 1x2 plates that just refuse to come apart. (http://www.bricklink.com/catalogItemPic.asp?P=3023) But don't let it bother you. Just pull out the Brick Separator, and those troublesome one-byes will be apart in three seconds. Well, if you do it right. For some bricks, you just pull and they come apart. But with many plates, there's a trick. You have to build around the bottom plate until only the top one can be seen. Then you can pull the top one off. If you used a plate larger than either of the ones you are trying to pry apart, the bottom will be no problem. (The reason I rated the building experience anything is because it's required. My real rating for it is 0)

author: J14T14
title: Was Great, But Doesn't Hold Up Today
review:
This set was probably a great thing to get in 1990 since piece removers weren't as common back then as they are today. A tool that could remove bricks and plates from each other was really nice then and it still is today, but this set doesn't hold up.

The picture on the packaging can make some people think that this comes with some extra pieces to make the little figure, but this is not true. The set only comes with one piece remover, so this is a little deceiving.

The reason why this set doesn't hold up today is because of the newer piece remover design. The new piece remover comes in every set that is over $50 while the old one came out in a select few sets such as this one.

Overall, I think that this set is only nice to get today if you want something to remind you of LEGO's history.
